title: Verify the deployment
content:
This topic describes how to verify an Operations Platform deployment.

To verify the deployment by ensuring that all the pods are up and running, perform the following steps:

  1.  Run the following command on the control plane or bastion node to see the pod status in a namespace: 
    kubectl get pods -n <application namespace>

    Example:

    The STATUS column indicates the current lifecycle state of the pod.  For example, Pending, Running, Completed, Init, CrashLoopBackoff. You will see many pods in Init state, the state eventually changes to PodInitializing, and then to  Running. 

    In addition, if the pod state is Running, check the READY column to see if the pod is fully started. The READY column indicates that out of the total number of containers available how many are running.  

    For example, 1/2 signifies that out of two containers, one is running. A pod fully starts when all the containers inside the pod start running.

    The pod lifecycle state may take approximately 45 minutes to change.

    It is not recommended to downscale the bookkeeper, broker, and zookeeper pods after deploying the application as this might result in application failure.

  2. Run the following command to get the pods that are not running:

    kubectl get pods --all-namespaces -o wide | awk -F " *|/" '($3!=$4 || $5!="Running") && $5!="Completed" {print $0}'

    After the 45 minute waiting period, if the pod is still not in the Running state, it may require some troubleshooting. 

    You can further verify the status of each pod by running the following commands:

    1. If the pod is in  Pending, ImagePullErorr, or not yet in Running state with all containers started(for example, 2/2), then you can get more information about such pods by running the following command:   
      kubectl describe pod <pod name> -n <application namespace>
    2. You can view the logs for a container by running the following command:  
      kubectl logs <pod name> -n <application namespace> -c <container name> [-f]

      Run the following command to get <container name>:  
      kubectl describe pod <pod name> -n <application namespace>

      If you omit -c <container name>, the output displays the list of container names for that pod. 
      -f is optional.  It behaves like tail -f by streaming the output and not exiting until you enter ctrl-c.
       Example:  
      # kubectl describe pod bvd-www-deployment-55c6f745d-8zf45 -n ops-platform 

# kubectl logs bvd-www-deployment-74b895c686-x7bps -n ops-platform -c bvd-www

Verify the URL access

To verify the URLs, complete the following tasks:

  1. Identify the external access host and external access port. If you have installed using CLI, run the following commands to get the values  global.externalAccessHost and global.externalAccessPort from your values.yaml file. For example: 
    helm get values <helm deployment name> -n <application namespace> -o json | jq '.global.externalAccessHost'
helm get values <helm deployment name> -n <application namespace> -o json | jq '.global.externalAccessPort'
  2. With the Operations Platform deployment, you can access the following URLs: 
    Capabilities Applications URL
    All User Management UI https://<FQDN_of_the_external_access_host>:<port_number_of_the_external_access_host>/idm-admin
    All License Management UI https://<FQDN_of_the_external_access_host>:<port_number_of_the_external_access_host>/autopass
    Stakeholder dashboards Operations Cloud UI https://<FQDN_of_the_external_access_host>:<port_number_of_the_external_access_host>/ui
  3. Log in using your application administrator user. For example, "admin" and the administrator password.

If you have imported your own CA signed certificates, and see a Not Secure message on the browser, then your certificates are incorrect. Follow the steps mentioned in Request certificates (External kubernetes) from OMT documentation to get the right certificates.

After all the pods are in running state, the tenant is in activated state, and the create-op-tenant job is in completed state, proceed to install the application.
